alert.note: Alert for Gibson; Knox; Posey (Indiana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued March 17 at 10:13AM EDT until March 19 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Indianapolis
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Indiana...Illinois... White River at Hazleton affecting Knox and Gibson Counties. Wabash River at Riverton affecting Sullivan, Knox, Crawford and Lawrence Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Indiana... Illinois... Wabash River at Mount Carmel affecting Edwards, Posey, Wabash, White, Gibson, Knox and Gallatin Counties. .Ongoing flooding will continue along portions of the Lower White and Wabash Rivers due to prior rainfall. Minor flooding is occurring, which primarily impacts river roads, parks, and agricultural land. The last of the flooding on the lower reaches of the Wabash and White Rivers is expected to end by early Saturday. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL SATURDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Wabash River at Mount Carmel. * WHEN...Until Saturday morning. * IMPACTS...At 22.0 feet, Flood waters begin to affect residents of East Mt. Carmel, Indiana. Fifth Street that parallels river closes. Twin restaurant along the river also closes. Several local river roads flood. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:45 AM CDT Thursday /8:45 AM EDT Thursday/ the stage was 22.2 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 7:45 AM CDT Thursday /8:45 AM EDT Thursday/ was 23.1 feet. - Forecast...The river will fall below flood stage tomorrow evening to 10.5 feet and then begin rising early Monday afternoon. It will then rise again to 11.3 feet early Tuesday afternoon. It will fall to 10.9 feet and then begin rising Tuesday evening. It will then rise again to 11.3 feet Thursday evening. It will fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 19.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/ind. This statement will be updated within the next 12 to 24 hours.
